Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
February 2021 
 
 
Mongolia: Supporting Micro, Small, and Medium-
Ger
sized Enterprises in the   Areas of Ulaanbaatar 
during COVID-19 Crisis

Policy.

I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
 
1.  On 12 December 2013, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved a multitranche 
financing  facility  (MFF)  for  the  Ulaanbaatar  Urban  Services  and  Ger  Areas  Development 
Investment Program,1 comprising three tranches, and with a revised implementation period of 10 
years or until 11 December 2023.2 Based on the updated financing plan, the total program cost 
is  $344.2  million,  of  which  $163.7  million  will  be  financed  by  ADB;  $120.2  million  by  the 
Municipality of Ulaanbaatar (MUB); and up to €50.0 million ($60.3 million equivalent at the time 
of approval) parallel cofinancing by the European Investment Bank.3 The program's impact is 
improved living conditions in Ulaanbaatar. Its outcome is a network of livable, competitive, and 
inclusive subcenters in Ulaanbaatar's ger (yurt or traditional tents) areas.4 The program has four 
outputs:  (i)  roads  and  urban  services  are  expanded  within  the  targeted  subcenters  and 
connectivity between subcenters is improved; (ii) economic and public services in subcenters are 
improved; (iii) service providers become more efficient; and (iv) institutions and capacity for urban 
development, program management, and service delivery are strengthened. The framework 
financing agreement was signed on 9 December 2013 and ratified by the Parliament of Mongolia 
on 23 May 2014.  
 
2.  Tranche 1 of the MFF program was approved on 17 December 2013, with a revised 
closing date of 30 June 2021. It supports the city master plan in developing the Selbe and 
Bayankhoshuu subcenters with total ADB financing of $53.7 million.5 As of 15 December 2020, 
the overall implementation progress is at 89.4% against 92.8% of elapsed implementation period. 
The  overall  contract  award  was  at  $46.8 million  (87.1%)  while  total  disbursement  was  at 
$40.0 million  (74.5%).  Tranche  2  was  approved  on  31 March  2017,  with  closing  date  of 
28 February 2022. It aims to extend the urban infrastructure and social facilities upgrading and 
spatial restructuring to Dambadarjaa and Denjiin subcenters and provide additional investments 
in Selbe and Bayankhoshuu subcenters with total ADB financing of $66.4 million from ADB.6 As 
of 15 December 2020, the overall implementation progress is at 22.6% against 75.5% of elapsed 
implementation period. The overall contract award was at $19.2 million (28.9%) while total 
disbursement was at $13.9 million (20.9%). Tranche 3 was approved on 26 June 2020 and is 
expected to become effective by Q1 2021, with loan closing date of 11 December 2023.7 It will 
extend investments in priority infrastructure, public facilities, and capacity building to develop 
Tolgoit and Sharkhad subcenters. There has been no change in outputs of either tranche 1 or 
tranche 2, and their performance is rated on track. 
 
3.  Three  technical  assistance  (TA)  projects  were  approved  by  ADB  to  support  the 
implementation of the MFF program: (i) Ulaanbaatar Pro-Poor Urban Redevelopment Support 
System for Ger Areas, approved in 2017 to pilot information and communication technology tools 
for ger area redevelopment;8 (ii) Livelihood Support Demonstration in Ger Areas, a small-scale 
TA approved in 2018, to support the poor and vulnerable households adversely affected by 
involuntary resettlement under tranche 1 of the MFF program;9 and (iii) Capacity Building for 
 
1  ADB. Mongolia: Ulaanbaatar Urban Services and Ger Areas Development Investment Program.   
2  On 16 April 2020, the President approved the extension of the MFF availability period from 9 years to 10 years (or 
from 31 December 2022 to 11 December 2023) to ensure the timely implementation of tranche 3. 
3  The financing plan was updated during project processing for tranche 3. ADB financing includes $3.7 million grant 
from Urban Environmental Infrastructure Fund under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility administered by ADB. 
4  Ger areas refer to the vast and low-density peri-urban areas in Ulaanbaatar. 
5  ADB. Mongolia: Ulaanbaatar Urban Services and Ger Areas Development Investment Program - Tranche 1. 
6  ADB. Mongolia: Ulaanbaatar Urban Services and Ger Areas Development Investment Program - Tranche 2. 
7  ADB. Mongolia: Ulaanbaatar Urban Services and Ger Areas Development Investment Program - Tranche 3. 
8  ADB. Mongolia: Ulaanbaatar Pro-Poor Urban Redevelopment Support System for Ger Areas. 
9  ADB. Mongolia: Livelihood Support Demonstration in Ger Areas.

2 
Sustainable Livelihood Support in Ger Areas, approved in 2019, to provide capacity development 
support to the MUB to institutionalize an approach to plan, design, and implement livelihood 
support programs that target affected households whose livelihoods were adversely affected by 
involuntary resettlement.10 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) play a fundamentally important role 
in economic development and job creation in Mongolia. At the end of 2017, MSMEs comprised 
77% of total registered business entities and generated about 70% employment.11 In light of that, 
tranche 1 of the MFF program focused  on (i) social and economic facilities development, including 
business incubator centers (BICs); and (ii) institutional and capacity development that supports 
community participation and MSMEs development in its overall financing plan. As part of that 
support, in January 2020, a preliminary survey among MSMEs was conducted in Bayankhoshuu 
and Selbe subcenters. The survey results showed that demand for financing and capacity building 
was high among MSMEs—more than 70% of the enterprises required loan financing, 50% aimed 
to expand their businesses, 27% were in need of equipment, and 14% need to improve their 
finance and accounting knowledge. However, the survey findings indicated limited access to 
finance for MSMEs. Only 35% of the MSME business owners received bank loans, while 65% 
were receiving loans with monthly interest rates higher than 3.5% from private lenders, non-
banking financial institutions (NBFIs), savings and credit cooperatives (SCCs), or pawnshops. 
Stringent collateral requirements and financial illiteracy were identified as the barriers for access 
to finance among MSMEs. Of the enterprises surveyed, 56% reported difficulties in providing 
collateral for loans, and 40% in presenting their financial report and/or proof of income. 
 
5.   The government has undertaken various measures to improve access to finance for 
MSMEs. For example, a small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) development agency have 
been established for the implementation of SME policies, and promoting better targeted and more 
transparent funding to SMEs. In addition, the government has launched other measures such as 
establishment of the credit guarantee and employment creation funds to improve MSMEs' access 
to finance, and initiated training programs and advisory services for MSMEs capacity building. 
However, it is reported that the benefits of these support measures have not yet effectively 
reached  the  MSMEs  nor  have  these  measures  been  efficient  and  effective  to  MSMEs 
development.  International  institutions  also  have  worked  closely  with  the  government  and 
provided support targeting at MSMEs. For example, ADB has recently provided three loans to 
improve the availability of financing with longer tenor to MSMEs through financial institutions.12  
  
6.  Pandemic impacts. The outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has negatively 
impacted Mongolian businesses, particularly MSMEs. A survey conducted by ADB's East Asia 
Department between April and May 2020 among MSMEs in Ulaanbaatar and nine other provinces, 
indicates that COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionally impacted MSMEs in Mongolia compared 
to the larger businesses, with the MSMEs in urban areas having been negatively affected to a 
higher degree. Smaller and informal businesses face key challenges due to the COVID-19 
 
10 ADB. Mongolia: Capacity Building for Sustainable Livelihood Support in Ger Areas. 
11 L. Boojoo. 2019. Leveraging SME Finance through Value Chains in the CAREC Landlocked Economies: Case of 
Mongolia. ADBI Working Paper Series. No. 1019. Tokyo: Asian Development Bank Institute. 
12 ADB. Mongolia: Senior Loan to Khan Bank for Supporting Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprises; ADB. 
Mongolia: Supporting the Credit Guarantee System for Economic Diversification and Employment Project; and ADB. 
Mongolia: Agriculture and Rural Development Project.

3 
pandemic travel restrictions and lockdowns, including cash shortages, difficulties in making 
investment and financing decisions, and difficulties in paying employees, resulting in layoffs.13 
Since MSMEs generate about 70% of employment in Mongolia, disruption in their businesses can 
lead to losses of income for households relying heavily on wages and personal businesses, 
intensifying  the  impact  of  COVID-19  on  households,  especially  from  poor  and  vulnerable 
populations. In response, the government has brought forward a series of economic stimulus 
measures to accelerate the post COVID-19 recovery, some of which are relevant to MSMEs.14 
  
7.  Providing timely support to MSMEs is therefore critical for not only reducing income 
inequality and unemployment, enhancing social stability, and strengthening private sector, but 
also aligning with the government's initiatives to accelerate the post COVID-19 recovery and 
improve  social  resilience.  Improving  financial  literacy  of  MSMEs,  providing  information  on 
concessional financing, and providing equipment for business development and expansion are 
identified as key, yet low-hanging fruits for MSMEs development. In addition, as the upgrading of 
Selbe  and  Bayankhoshuu  subcenters  under  tranche  1  is  almost  complete,  new  business 
opportunities will be created to attract and accommodate influx of population. With the support 
from this transaction TA, MSMEs are expected to quickly seize those emerging opportunities and 
play a vital role in maintaining a robust function of subcenters by providing services to residents 
and creating economies in the post COVID-19 recovery period. In the long run, this TA is expected 
to make MSMEs adaptive and prepared for the wider transformation and urbanization of ger areas, 
including all subcenters under the other tranches of the MFF program, synergizing with existing 
and future urban development work.15  
 
8.  This TA is not included in the approved country operations business plan for Mongolia, 
2019–2021, but it is well aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030, which supports the operational priority 
on making cities more livable and ADB's country partnership strategy for Mongolia, 2017–2020,16 
on catalyzing urban economic growth.17  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Capacity, needs, and opportunities for micro, small, and medium-sized 
enterprises to access finance assessed. This output will support detailed and focused survey 
of  the  MSMEs  (with  gender  consideration  and  sex-disaggregated  data)  in  the  Selbe  and 
Bayankhoshuu subcenters, and collect information on the supply side of available financing in the 
market.  The  survey  will  collect  granular  information  on  MSMEs financial  and  non-financial 
conditions and assess their (i) financial capacity (monthly and annual turnover); (ii) access to 
financial sources and services from banks, NBFIs, and financial technology (FinTech) companies; 
(iii) capacity to prepare documentation (financial reports, proof of income, project proposal, 
business plan, etc.); (iv) assets and means of business and production, and equipment needs; 
(v) management capacity; and (vi) business mindset. It will also assess the impacts of COVID-19 
on their businesses, needs to adapt to a post-COVID-19 environment, and other data that are 
required by different stakeholders. To ensure access to information on available financing in the 
 
13 ADB. 2020. Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprises and the Informal Sector in Mongolia: COVID-19 Impacts 
and Options for a Sustainable Recovery. ADB Briefs [No. 160]. Manila.  
14 For example, on 25 March 2020, the government revised and approved the regulation on "Concessional lending, 
selection, sub-lending, repayment and monitoring from the Small and Medium Enterprise Development Fund" 
reflecting changes to the amount of loans for MSMEs and concessional loan procedure, reducing requirements for 
sub-lending commercial banks, and increasing the amount of regional loans issued. 
15 Such as Mongolia: Ulaanbaatar Green Affordable Housing and Resilient Urban Renewal Sector Project. 
16 ADB. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 4: Making Cities More Livable, 2019–2024; and ADB. Country 
Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of Economic Difficulty.  
17 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 8 January 2021.

4 
market for MSMEs development, the TA will establish and maintain a database on (i) financial 
institutions operating in the subcenters, including commercial banks, NBFIs, as well as FinTech 
companies  and  their  loan  rates;  (ii) successfully  operating  community-established  and  led 
financial institutions including SCCs, savings groups, and their membership (whether or not 
MSMEs are members) in Ulaanbaatar; and (iii) leasing companies and their available products 
and services in Ulaanbaatar. This output will provide a clear picture of  the financial situation, 
access to finance, and non-financial issues of the MSMEs and financial institutions operating in 
the subcenters; and will determine how  financial institutions can better meet the needs of the 
MSMEs and the feasibility of establishing community-established and led financial institutions in 
the Selbe and Bayankhoshuu subcenters 
10.  Output  2:  Gender-responsive  capacities  and  knowledge  for  micro,  small,  and 
medium-sized enterprises to access finance enhanced. This output will carry out the following 
activities: (i) trainings and workshops on collateral (movable and immovable) requirements for 
commercial banks and non-bank lenders (NBFIs, SCCs, leasing firms, and FinTech companies), 
preparation  of  documentations  on  collateral,  financial  reports  and  proof  of  income,  project 
proposals,  business  plans,  and  other  relevant  trainings;  (ii)  trainings  and  workshops  on 
community-established and led financial institutions for access to loan funding, including good 
practices on governance, structure, and operation of successful community-established and led 
financial institutions; (iii) visits to successful community-established and led financial institutions 
in the ger areas for MSME representatives; and (iv) face-to-face mentor-led on-the-job trainings 
in BICs in the subcenters to complement the classroom trainings and workshops conducted in (i) 
and (ii), and will involve trainings where MSME representatives such as business development 
committees will be guided and assisted by mentors on how to prepare and compile relevant 
documentation and how to run community-established and led financial institutions. An MSME 
support office will be established and run by a mentor in each BIC in Selbe and Bayankhoshuu 
subcenters. The workshops and trainings will be organized taking into consideration the gender 
issues and hardships encountered by women, and will target a minimum of 50% of the participants 
will be women. The workshops and trainings will also include presentations on (i) how MSMEs 
can access financing support available under ADB-supported projects (footnote 12) and public 
and private institutions; and (ii) customized international best practices for MSMEs development, 
including lessons from ADB's Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative and Supporting 
Internationalization of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises in the Greater Mekong Subregion. 
 
11.  Output 3: Equipment to develop and expand business opportunities for micro, small, 
and medium-sized enterprises provided. This output will primarily target micro and small-sized 
enterprises. The following activities will be conducted: (i) based on survey results from output 1, 
the consultant and the MFF program management office (PMO) will assess business needs and 
develop criteria to select MSMEs to receive equipment, considering factors such as gender 
inclusiveness, vulnerability, competitiveness, and sustainability;18 (ii) based on (i), the consultant 
will procure equipment for MSMEs business development and expansion; and (iii) the feasibility 
of providing equipment through leasing companies to MSMEs will be assessed using the survey 
results in output 1, and the feasibility results will provide insights on the market for the leasing 
industry  and  potential  business  opportunities  for  future  assistance  to  support  MSMEs 
development. 
 
 
18 ADB will review and approve (i) the selection criteria developed by the consultant and PMO, and (ii) the list of resulting 
MSME beneficiaries. Equipment support will be demand-driven and include equipment and tools to support 
enhancing efficiencies of the MSME operations, such as computers and printers, mechanized welding equipment to 
welding units, modernized sewing machines to a handicraft business, etc.

5 
12.  Design and monitoring framework. The TA will not result to a change in the design and 
monitoring framework of the ongoing MFF program and its tranches. The TA will enhance the 
quality of outputs without any change to the targeted results indicators. In particular, it will facilitate 
the delivery of outputs 2 and 4 under the MFF program.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $310,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-others) resources special pool for COVID-
19 response. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, 
secretarial assistance including meeting translation, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants, and 
procure goods. The executing agency will be the MUB, supported by the PMO administering the 
MFF program. Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  February 2021–February 2022 
Executing agency  Municipality of Ulaanbaatar 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Firm: Consultants'  MSME development  $128,000 
qualification selection  (national, 25 person-months) 
Procurementa  To be procured by consultants 
Request for quotations  10 contracts (estimated)  $157,000 
Disbursement  Disbursement  of  TA  resources  will  follow  ADB's  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). 
Asset turnover or disposal  All goods purchased under the TA will be turned over to the executing 
arrangement upon TA completion  agency upon completion of TA activities. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank; MSME = micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises; TA = technical assistance.  
a  Procurement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
Source: ADB. 
 
15.  Consulting services. A national consulting firm will be engaged using consultants' 
qualification selection method with biodata technical proposal, for total consulting inputs of 
25 person-months. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions.19  
 
16.  Procurement of equipment. Procurement of goods shall be undertaken by the consultant 
recruited under the TA and shall be carried out in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions. 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Supporting Micro, Small, and Medium-sized Enterprises in the Ger 
Areas of Ulaanbaatar during COVID-19 Crisis, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
19 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

6  Appendix 1

goods purchased under the TA will be turned over to the executing agency upon completion of TA activities. The
